name: Sam
comment info: For this assignment, students were asked to pick a graph that interested them and interpret it in as many ways as possible. This graph first caught my eye because of its relevance to my real life and how it has and will impact me in the years to come/years past. What I notice about this graph is that from the 1980s-2000 hurricanes and other natural disasters didn’t happen very often and were not nearly as costly. I also noticed that the two highest years, cost wise, are 2005 and 2018. In 2018, there were four major natural disasters that cost millions of dollars. While in 2005, there was one major disaster that was so devastating it cost about ¾ of what 2018 had brought. These pieces of data show me that in more recent times natural disasters have been increasing at a concerning rate and this could potentially be due to human errors and other factors. Secondly, what I wonder from this graph is exactly why these natural disasters have increased so much in recent years. I can’t think of any major reasons that these disasters would sky rocket so high in 2018. Another thing that I can wonder from this graph is why Hurricane Katrina was so costly. I wasn’t born yet for this hurricane, so I’m not exactly sure the damage it caused. Lastly, I also am wondering if in 2019 and all the years after that the natural disaster rate will be as high as it was in 2018. I’m not sure if this is easily predictable, but I believe it can be solved. (cont in next post)

name: Winnie Wilson
comment info:
Are hurricanes starting to become a common tragedy?In graph A I notice that by using a dot plot the
different years are portrayed by the amount of hurricanes that made landfall in the continental United
States that year. I also observe that some years like 1982 did not have any hurricanes, while 1985 had 7
hurricanes. I wonder what hurricanes are qualified to be in this graph, and whether or not it is an
exclusive graph.
Natural disasters are a big disaster in the U.S. economy. In graph B I notice that by using a bar graph The
total cost of major disasters is shown per year. For example, you can see that in 200 there was slightly
more then 200 billion dollars spent on natural disasters, while 2000 had around a 10 billion loss.
Hurricane Katrina caused great devastation and loss by having a leading 161 billion dollar destruction fee,
and not far behind is Hurricane Harvey with a 125 billion dollar destruction fee.
The main difference between the graphs is that graph A illustrates only the number of hurricanes that made
landfall while graph B illustrates all natural disasters and the cost of the disasters. A similarity could be
how each year is shown with a number following it.

name: P.4 GIS Kearny Highschool
comment info: The Period 4 GIS students from Kearny High School in San Diego, noticed that in Graph A there was a spike of hurricanes between 1980-1990 but not a lot of natural disaster funds were spent. They also noticed that Graph B includes all natural disasters and not just hurricanes like Graph A. The students wondered if the hurricanes were weaker before the 1990s? The cost of natural disasters has steadily increased over the years. Has the cost of rebuilding increased significantly? 2017 was the most expensive year in natural disasters. The California wildfire costs were 18 billion last year and Hurricane Katrina was the most expensive natural disaster overall. We were wondering if the flooding that occurs after a hurricane has gotten worse over the years and caused recovery costs to increase? Would inflation also be something that would increase recovery costs.

name: Shoup
comment info:
Next class wondered why Hurricane Sandy was NOT included in red as part of the 2012 damage report?

Also wondering if the hurricanes depicted in red were those that received what was perceived as slow response time by the current administrations?

We noticed that the hurricanes were identified by name and not by location.

Is 'cost' calculated according to property damage/loss or is expense of relief and cleanup included?

Does response time have anything to do with money spent?  Social media increases the speed with which we learn about natural disasters, so might that associate with money spent in recovery?

Comparing 2004 to 2005, the counts of hurricanes are equal but the expense ratio appears to be roughly 3:1.  Is this related to the intensity of just 1 hurricane?

Population density shifts in the last 10 years creates more structures which are put at risk in a hurricane.

We noticed that the CA wildfires were highlighted in 2017, but the expense is not in step with the other damage estimates given.  Is that related to overall land mass affected?

name: AP-CSP Kearny High School
comment info: The Period 2, AP-Computer Science Principles students of Kearny High School in San Diego noticed that there were a higher number of hurricanes between 1985-1986 yet they did not have high costs in damage as other natural disasters. We wonder if that was because the hurricanes were not as strong or if the cost to repair infrastructure was lower. We also noticed that disaster costs of Hurricane Katrina were more than Hurricane Maria, Irma and the California wildfires from last year. Graph A only shows the number of hurricanes from 1900 until 2017 while Graph B shows all natural disasters from 1980 until last year. Graph B only shows damage costs if they are over 1 billion dollars. Wildfire damages cost less than hurricane damages. We think that is because flooding from the hurricanes affects more people and the fires tend to be in lower populated areas.

name: Moderator Leigh
comment info:
Have you ever seen a time series displayed using a dotplot or a bar graph? Did you notice the two large outliers among the total cost of major natural disasters (2005 and 2017)? Here’s hoping for a natural-disaster free remainder of 2018! 

Jane of Milwaukee wrote a catchy headline that described these graphs well, "Disasters over the Decades".  Good noticing and wondering leads to snappy headlines.

Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.  You can continue to post responses. Talk to your classmates and read the moderators’ replies. Dig deeper into what the graph shows.  Perhaps you will find more things to notice, wonder, claim or conjecture. Please check back on Thursday afternoon, September 20 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and two Stat Nuggets. And join us next Wednesday, September 26 for the next "What's Going On In This Graph?".  I think it might possibly have to do with fast food restaurants, unless we have a Hurricane Florence graph.  Signing off -- Erica in Waynesburg, Pennsylvania, and Leigh Nataro in Easton, Pennsylvania. Visit the "What's Going On In This Graph?" archives to keep responding. Hope to see you next week!

name: Shoup
comment info:
Why is the incidence of hurricanes remaining relatively stable over time while the costs associated are escalating?  Population density changing near the coastline without regard to common sense perhaps?

We wonder about the definition of 'hurricane': at least a Level 1 at landfall, or at least a Level 1 at inception?  Even tropical depressions cause significant damage without a 'hurricane' classification.

We'd be interested to see a comparative measure of hurricane severity.

Why doesn't the bar chart trace damage amounts back to 1900, to align with the dotplot?

Are the dollar amounts over the 37-year period adjusted for inflation?

replies.comment info: @Shoup You have noticed a key relationship between the graphs (stable hurricane rates and escalating costs).  And you asked many insightful questions.  Note that the graphs are not from the same source and that may be why the graphs cover different time periods.  Can you think of any other reasons why there would be escalating costs over the past decade?

name: Period 1 - GIS, Kearny High School
comment info: The period 1 students of Kearny High School in San Diego noticed that 1980 had a lot of hurricanes, however the costs for natural disasters for the same time period were lower. We think that is because hurricanes and their destruction are much worse now. We also noticed that the costs for natural disasters have progressively increased over the years. Graph B shows the costs of all natural disasters but Graph A only shows the number of hurricanes. We wonder if there were other natural disasters that occurred during those time periods such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, tornadoes and rain/snow and flooding.  We also wonder how much an impact climate change and population increases have had on the costs of natural disasters over the years.

replies.comment info: @Period 1 - GIS, Kearny High School Thanks for participating this week.  You have made some great observations. It's good to notice that graph B had other natural disasters, while graph A only had hurricanes.  People like me from the east coast don't think as much about earthquakes or tornados.  Why do you think climate change and population change would increase the costs? What sort of data would you need to test your theory?

name: Cassie
comment info: Although the amount of hurricanes that made landfall in the continental US seems to be relatively similar throughout the years, the cost of the major natural disasters has drastically increased and forms a left skew. I wonder of this is due to a larger population of people living in specific areas, the increase in costs over the years, or the severity of the storm and it's damage.

replies.comment info: @Cassie You have effectively compared the graphs - one staying relatively the same over the years (number of hurricanes) and one that shows a sharp increase over the years (cost). Your wonderings as to the difference - larger population, increase of cost and severity of storms - seem to make sense. What other information (data or graphs) would you want to have to test your wonderings?  Can you think of a catchy headline to go with the graphs?

replies.name: o
replies.comment info: @Cassie your comment stated many facts that we agree with and like about the part about it being relatively similar.

name: Moderator Leigh
comment info: This is quite an intereting pair of graphs this week.  Besides looking at the graphs individually, think about how the graphs work together.  What story do they tell?  I look forward to moderating your responses and comments.

name: Amy
comment info: We noticed that in graph A each dot represents one hurricane.  Between 1930 and 1980, the frequency of hurricanes seems very predictable, with at least one almost every year.  After 1980 however, it gets very unpredictable with some years having 6 or 7 hurricanes and some having only 1 or none at all.  We also noticed, when we compared graph A and B, that there were a lot of hurricanes in 1985, and yet the cost for natural disasters for that year was relatively low.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Amy - You have noticed some important observations. I wonder why the total cost in 1985 was relatively low? That also makes me wonder why the total cost in 2005 and 2017 were so great. Keep noticing and wondering!

name: Casey
comment info: Very cool. Very nice.

name: Moderator Erica
comment info:
Welcome to “What’s Going On in This Graph?”. 

Today’s graphs show the number and effect of natural disasters in the United States. Please study the graph and, from 9 am – 2 pm E.T., give us your responses online to these three questions. (On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.)   What do you NOTICE in these graphs?   What do you WONDER? What are you curious about that come from what you notice in the graphs?  What’s GOING ON in these graphs? 

Write a catchy headline that captures the graphs’ main idea.  If your headline makes a claim, tell us what you noticed that supports your claim.

 The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with the headline.   Then, read some responses. Click on "Reply" to an interesting response to get a discussion going. Learn different perspectives when you read what other students have to say about your response.   We look forward to reading your discoveries.

name: Jane
comment info: I notice that both graphs depict the damage hurricanes/natural disasters cause both in terms of physical landfall and cost. I wonder why in 2005 Graph A correlates to the high cost of Graph B but in the 1980s there were similar natural disasters (Graph A) that don't seem to cause any change in the 80's in terms of cost (Graph B). Although the gravity of the storms in the 80s seem as severe as the ones in 2005, the cost barely rises and not nearly to the degree as the 2005 depiction. I think the graphs are trying to indicate the cause and effect of natural disasters to the cost of reparations after the fact. I would name this graph: Disasters over the Decades.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Jane - Great observations! I love the name you came up with for the graphs. Isn't it interesting that although there are not substantially more hurricanes occurring that the cost of the damage has been so great in recent years? I wonder why that is?
